newsitem.title: NIGERIA: NIGERIAN SHARE TRADERS DON'T EXPECT SWIFT UPTURN.
newsitem.headline: NIGERIAN SHARE TRADERS DON'T EXPECT SWIFT UPTURN.

text.p: Nigerian shares slipped further on Friday and dealers said they didn't expect a swift upturn from the current slide.
The all-share index closed at 8133.93 from 8148.80 on Thursday.
The index is down over 2.3 percent in the past week and has fallen 7.6 percent since share prices began to slip in late April.
"If in the off season we have seen prices falling, the trend is likely continue to the end of the year," analyst Tunde Ayeni of CSL Stockbrokers said.
Some dealers still pin hopes of recovery on the release of capital spending funds by the military government, seven months after they were due.
But pessimists say that small investors, who traditionally account for a high proportion of shares traded on the stock exchange, tend to need to realise assets towards the end of the year.
"Parents will be paying school fees in September and then in December they will be spending lots of cash for the Christmas season," said Niyi Opeodu of Leads Investment.
Oil marketing companies looked dismal in Friday trading, with food and cement sectors little better.
African Petroleum fell to 45.50 naira, down 30 kobo. Unipetrol at 64.00 naira, fell 50 kobo and Texaco finished 15 kobo lower at 37.65 naira.
West African Portland Cement Company (WAPCO) and Ashaka Cement were respectivce 10 kobo losers at 60.00 naira and 12.40 naira.
Cadbury and Nigerian Bottling Company sagged by 10 kobo apiece at 33.40 naira and 49.80 naira respectively. Tyre maker Dunlop slipped by 10 kobo to 9.50 naira.
Healthcare firm Smithkline Beecham went ex-dividend at 5.40 naira, 25 kobo lower.
Guaranty Trust Bank fell 22 kobo to 5.28 naira but NAL Merchant Bank shot up 43 kobo at 9.18 naira on its positive full year result and news of a bonus issue of three shares for two.
Insurers AIICO rose 31 kobo to 15.51 naira. Prestige ended five kobo more at 6.35 naira and Crusader finished three kobo up at 1.33 naira.
United Textiles closed 10 kobo stronger at 5.90 naira, but Aba Textiles was two kobo down at 3.18 naira.
